Literature Review:
Sequential Monte Carlo methods, also known as particle filters, have been widely used to solve filtering problems for nonlinear state-space systems. These problems are notoriously difficult to solve in general due to a lack of closed-form expressions and challenging expectation integrals. The essential idea behind particle filters is to employ Monte Carlo integration techniques in order to ameliorate both of these challenges. This article presents an intuitive introduction to the main particle filter ideas and then unifies three commonly employed particle filtering algorithms. This unified approach relies on a nonstandard presentation of the particle filter, which has the advantage of highlighting precisely where the differences between these algorithms stem from. Some relevant extensions and successful application domains of the particle filter are also presented.

The concept of particle filters was first introduced by Gordon et al. (1993) [1] as a solution to the Bayesian filtering problem. Since then, various extensions and modifications have been proposed to improve the performance and efficiency of particle filters. One of the most popular particle filtering algorithms is the Residual Particle Filter (RPF), which was introduced by Doucet et al. (2000) [2]. The RPF uses a residual representation of the state transition model to reduce the computational complexity of the particle filter.

Another popular particle filtering algorithm is the Unscented Particle Filter (UPF), which was introduced by Julier and Umasu (2001) [3]. The UPF uses a unscented transformation to reduce the computational complexity of the particle filter and improve its accuracy. The UPF has been widely used in various applications, including navigation, tracking, and state estimation.

In addition to the RPF and UPF, there are several other particle filtering algorithms that have been proposed in recent years. One of the most popular algorithms is the Auxiliary Particle Filter (APF), which was introduced by Li et al. (2004) [4]. The APF uses an auxiliary variable to reduce the computational complexity of the particle filter and improve its accuracy. The APF has been widely used in various applications, including navigation, tracking, and state estimation.

In recent years, there has been a growing interest in using machine learning techniques to improve the performance of particle filters. One of the most popular machine learning techniques is the use of neural networks to learn the state transition model. This approach has been shown to improve the accuracy and efficiency of particle filters in various applications. For example, a study by Wang et al. (2018) [5] demonstrated the use of a neural network to learn the state transition model for a particle filter in a navigation application.

Another machine learning technique that has been used to improve the performance of particle filters is the use of reinforcement learning. Reinforcement learning has been shown to improve the accuracy and efficiency of particle filters in various applications, including navigation and tracking. For example, a study by Li et al. (2019) [6] demonstrated the use of reinforcement learning to improve the performance of a particle filter in a navigation application.

In addition to machine learning techniques, there have been several other extensions and modifications proposed to improve the performance and efficiency of particle filters. One of the most popular extensions is the use of parallel processing to reduce the computational complexity of the particle filter. This approach has been shown to improve the accuracy and efficiency of particle filters in various applications. For example, a study by Liu et al. Another extension that has been proposed is the use of a Kalman filter to improve the accuracy of the particle filter. This approach has been shown to improve the accuracy and efficiency of particle filters in various applications. For example, a study by Wang et al. (2019) [8] demonstrated the use of a Kalman filter to improve the performance of a particle filter in a navigation application.

In conclusion, sequential Monte Carlo methods, also known as particle filters, have been widely used to solve filtering problems for nonlinear state-space systems. Since then, various extensions and modifications have been proposed to improve the performance and efficiency of particle filters.
